Happy to discuss

Thank you for your response to my account of my difficulty in firstly: contacting my local health centre, and secondly: obtaining an appointment with a general practitioner. I have to make it clear that I know that this is not a local problem and so it would not be helpful to anyone to identify which health centre I am registered with. Local staff are not to blame. It is a National problem and one that can only be addressed on a National level, by the Scottish Government.  
To precis my thoughts on the subject:  
I fully understand that there are staff shortages both in administrative staff and medical staff positions and that this is increasing workloads and stress levels for those staff who remain working. However, that is not a reasonable excuse for the failure to provide a service.  
I have commented to reception staff on the difficulty that I have experienced in making initial contact with the health centre and I have been told that the phone lines cannot cope with the number of incoming calls and so the system 'crashes'. Surely that can be avoided by providing more phone lines?  
The difficulty in contacting the health centre opens up some new problems.  
The staff who answer the telephones at the health centre are clearly stressed. The last time that I managed to contact a staff member I did not even manage to complete my sentence before I was summarily dismissed and the call was cut off. We are told to contact NHS24 if we cannot contact our health professionals but that particular safety net does not work. You cannot provide individualised and personal health care on a telephone. The response of those who provide advice on 111, if they consider it to be a life threatening issue, is to advise people to phone 999. This then results in an ambulance being sent. This ties up two paramedics and one ambulance for a considerable period of time when all that would have been required in many cases would be a physical examination from a doctor. Obviously I also understand that there are many situations that cannot competently be dealt with in this way but that is a judgement that staff who answer the telephones on the NHS24 line cannot make and so an ambulance is summoned many more times than is really necessary.  
On the second point, that of obtaining an appointment with a doctor, I have just had a four week wait from visiting the health centre and requesting an appointment, to actually getting one, and even then my consultation was a phone call. When I asked for an actual consultation I was told that any appointment has to be a phone call in the first instance and then, if the doctor considers it necessary, a face to face appointment will be arranged at a later date. So how long are people supposed to wait for a face to face appointment? From this it would seem likely that it would be eight weeks from first contact to getting one's health issue addressed. Long enough for any genuine problem to become worse and long enough for those who had no real reason for requesting an appointment in the first place to lose interest and forget about it. Is this one of the reasons for the current system?  
We are told that a pharmacist is able to deal with minor health issues. What is a minor health issue? Health problems tend to get worse if neglected and I am certainly not going to stand in my pharmacy explaining intimate health issues with staff and customers listening in. I am aware that a 'private' room is available for consultations at a pharmacy but the concept of 'privacy' is relative and It does not measure up to my standards at my local chemist's shop.  
And so it is not a straightforward issue. I understand that and unless the health system is given a complete overhaul I do not see what can be done to lessen my concerns. I am not blaming local staff who are no doubt doing their best in difficult conditions. Certainly platitudes will do nothing to help. The whole system is at fault.

Binfield Surgery, like other practices are dealing with a high demand of patient calls at the present moment in time. signature: Blandford Medical Centre
body:
Dear Patient,
Thank you for your comments.
However, I am afraid the information you have is incorrect. We offer advanced booking via online or reception. We also offer online triage: simply complete the details and we will contact you to book an appointment. No need for you to even call the practice. All details can be found on our website.
However, the majority of GP appointments are same day booking for a very good reason, it protects the appointment system from patients that fail to attend.
Our nurse appointments are 95% face to face and all advanced booked. They had 2 hours of appointments wasted yesterday for patients that failed to turn up. This is not an isolated occurrence, this was the same throughout November.
This is utterly disgraceful, and we need to protect our system from those that are wasting appointments and preventing access to the practice for those that need it.
We are not still running a covid appointment system, we are running with a system that works for Braintree, and to expect all practices in different locations to run with the same system is unsafe. We all have different patient needs and our practice will run the way we need it in Braintree.
You are of course free to register elsewhere, simply because you are already registered already in Braintree does not stop a practice from being able to accept you. We are extremely accommodating and accept patients from other Braintree practices.
If you would like assistance with registering elsewhere our administration team will gladly help you.
Kind regards
Caroline Jones
Practice Manager

signature: Rowan Tree Practice
body:
Dear patient,
Thank you for your feedback.
We have received a lot comments regarding our phone system, and understand it presents limitations to our patients, and causes frustration.

It must be stressed that the service, and primary care is stretched beyond it's limit currently, and we are trying our best to provide the best care for our patients. The wait on our phones is a symptom of this increased demand, so your patience and ongoing understanding is appreciated. 

Our ICB has recently provided funding for a new cloud-based phone system, which offers some enhanced features which we hope will improve the experience for patients trying to reach us. This should be rolled out in in early 2023 the delay in the roll out has be delayed due to procurement and planning to help minimise the impact on our patients during the switchover.


We understand the importance and necessity of being able to post anonymously but it doesn't allow us to look in to and raise the individual case with our phone supplier.

If you would like us to look into this incident further with our supplier, please contact us via https://www.rowantreepractice.org.uk/SecureForm?FID=f7990146-c628-4f78-8c33-54b52b1c9ccc&FT=0&GP=67eb3a83-c72d-4ad4-9df1-d3e4d48d6e18

signature: Queens Avenue Surgery
body:
Dear Patient

Thank you for taking the time to leave feedback on our service. It appears that you understand the pressures on general practice and the challenges that we have faced due to Covid-19 during the past 3 years.

Our clinicians have changed the way they work and our receptionists have had to deal with the increase in patient frustration at our new ways of working.  This has been incredibly difficult at times and although we are very mindful of the strain on our patients we just want everyone to be kind.  We are very proud of the way our whole team have worked and adapted in the constantly changing environment.

We are pleased that you value the appointment options and our availability - through periods of staff shortages, we have worked hard to maintain reasonable wait times.  

Thank you again for your very kind words and support for the staff of Queens Avenue Surgery.

Tracy Bowden
Practice Manager

signature: Queens Avenue Surgery
body:
Dear Patient

Thank you for your feedback and please accept my apologies for the time it has taken me to respond to your comments.  I am very sorry to hear that you have experienced a less than satisfactory service.

We have been through a very difficult period and have experienced a number of staff changes and shortages.  We feel confident that this has greatly improved and hope that your more recent experiences have been more positive.

Please do not hesitate to contact me if you are not happy with the service you receive from any of our team as it is helpful for me to have the opportunity to discuss your concerns at the time.

Tracy Bowden
Practice Manager

signature: Queens Avenue Surgery
body:
Dear Patient

Thank you for your feedback and very kind words and understanding.  Patients have become accustomed to giving us brief details of their condition which does enable us to direct them to the correct person or service.  Our doctors also find it incredibly helpful to allow them to prioritise their work and have an indication of the patient's reason for contacting us.

I have been here nearly as long as you have been a patient, 25 years 5 months to be exact!  I am very proud to be a part of a fantastic clinical, reception and admin team who have been immensely challenged in recent times and your comments really do go a long way.  Thank you.

Tracy Bowden
Practice Manager

signature: Queens Avenue Surgery
body:
Dear Patient

I wish you well for the future and trust you are receiving a good service with your new surgery.  We are very fortunate to have a number of very good surgeries in this area, all of which work extremely hard to offer the best service possible.

Tracy Bowden
Practice Manager

signature: Lee-Anne Abel, NHS Tayside
body:
Dear Baby Jack  
Congratulations on the birth of your baby. I hope you are all settling well at home and are adapting to the many changes a new baby brings and enjoying the new memories that the arrival of a baby undoubtedly help you create.  
Thank you for your kind feedback; I am delighted to hear your birth experience was so positive and you were cared for with such kindness and attention to detail. It is reassuring to hear that your needs were met, discharge planning was in keeping with your wishes and that your tea and toast was very well received. You won't be surprised to hear that the tea and toast is often a profound memory for many...  
I will take great pride in sharing this with our teams and I am sure from your story that those directly responsible for those small acts that made such a big difference to you and your experience will recognise themselves. Such positive feedback is so valuable to staff and the kindness within your feedback is greatly appreciated.  
I would be interested to learn more relating to your experience within ward 38 and am happy to arrange a call with you if this is something you wish to discuss further to see how we could have made this a more positive part of the overall experience for you.  
Feedback; both positive and negative is welcomed within our service to help us learn and improve for the women and families we care for.  
Thank you!  
Warm Regards,

Thank you very much for submitting this positive feedback about the health visiting service, especially when you have a 13/14 month old who will be keeping you very busy.  
Feedback is extremely valuable for our service as it allows us to hear directly from parents which in turn provides opportunities to make changes and improvements based when these are required.  
Positive feedback reinforces the high standards of care being offered/provided by health visitors in our communities which is reassuring for health visitors, the P&K Heath Visiting Service and NHS Tayside.  
If you are agreeable, I would welcome an email from you providing the name of your health visitor so that I can share this story/feedback directly with her. My email address is audrey.rhind@nhs.scot  
Many thanks  
Audrey

signature: Roisin Dorrian, Lead Nurse, Cardiac Rehabilitation, Downe Hospital, South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
body:
Thank you for your positive feedback about our Cardiac Rehabilitation (CR) programme in Downe Hospital. It is very much appreciated that you took the time to share your journey especially as a cardiac event can have a major impact. We remain passionate about our service and the impact it can have on your recovery therefore having support on discharge from hospital is so important.  
CR is so much more than an exercise class and the regular review over the 8 weeks can address any potential issues so we can adjust medication, check BP and pulse and liaise with cardiology if required. The link between our hospital based cardiac rehab and then the Phase 4 gym programme is a positive step and hope it helps you further on your fitness journey.  
It is humbling to hear positive comments on our NHS as it undoubtably has faced many challenges especially the last few years.  
Keep up the good work- we wish you continued good health.  
Roisin Dorrian  
Cardiac Rehabilitation Nurse Specialist  
Downe Hospital  
SET

body:
Hello  
Thank you for taking the opportunity to provide the orthopaedic ward with feedback. I am pleased that you were satisfied with the nurses' efforts to care for you. Everybody is working hard. We will keep in mind when repositioning patients to ensure that the bed sheets are tidy. It is normal routine on our ward that the breakfast is giving out between 8.00 and 08.30. I apologise for the delay in you receiving your breakfast. Dinner trolley then comes to the ward at 12.00. The physiotherapist assesses all patients the first day after surgery as we encourage early mobilisation to prevent complications after surgery. the nursing staff try to give pain relief before physio work with patients.  
Your feedback will also be seen by the catering department.  
I take this opportunity to wish you a full recovery from your operation.  
Kind regards  
Clinical sister

Thank you for your review and we wish you a continued recovery and all the best for the future.  
Kind Regards  
Claire Lee  
Community Stroke Team Lead
